content.question: The conducting sphere in Figure 1 has a charge of <math alttext="negative Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and is electrically isolated so that there is no conducting path to or from the conducting object shown in Figure 2. The charges on the sphere are in equilibrium. The same charge <math alttext="negative Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is on the isolated conducting object. Which of the following correctly describes a change between the sphere in Figure 1 and the object in Figure 2?

choices.label: The charge is no longer located entirely on the surface of the object.
The electric field inside the object is no longer zero everywhere.
The electric potential is no longer the same at all points inside the object.
The electric field is no longer directed perpendicular to the surface at all points on the object.
The magnitude of the electric field is no longer the same at all points on the surface.

content.answer: The magnitude of the electric field is no longer the same at all points on the surface.
